There was a fear of dropping from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June just because the cyclist listened to some gentlemen who might have been overly confident or tough - talking. This is how the features of the setting affected the cyclist, highlighting the challenges and risks faced during the journey.

The cyclist placed his trust in a man who had limited knowledge of the world. He assumed the man would know the way to his destination. Taking the man's advice, the cyclist thought he'd reach his destination quickly, so he consumed his water rapidly. Soon, he realized he was out of water, and the park he was headed to was nowhere in sight. Frustrated and angry, the cyclist continued across the desert, growing tired and dehydrated. He passed a rough road filled with tumbleweeds and snakes but kept going until he spotted the “[Company Name] Juice” company. He rushed there, went into the bathroom, and drank some water. When he emerged, an old man offered directions, but the cyclist declined. In the end, the cyclist's trust in an ill - informed man led to a difficult and trying journey.

During the “Do not exceed speed limit” passage, the cyclist faces numerous hardships due to the setting. While lost, thirsty, and exhausted, the cyclist is in “The high deserts of California in June,” where the temperature is likely unbearable. This extreme heat causes the cyclist to tire and dehydrate more quickly than normal. Additionally, the road has many steep hills, as indicated by “over one long, crippling hill,” which requires a great deal of energy to climb. Moreover, the area is completely deserted, with “no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” This means that if the cyclist needs help, there is no one around. Overall, the setting negatively impacts the cyclist's journey, making it arduous and perilous.

The situation impacts the cyclist as the text initially mentions an old man. It also implies that the information is outdated. In other words, the cyclist should have simply followed the map from the start. This oversight led to a less - than - ideal situation for the cyclist.

In the stories “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit”, there are highly descriptive settings that significantly affect the cyclist. The effects vary depending on the settings, with some being positive and others harsh. The first described setting, “the cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them,” paints a vivid picture of the cyclist's destination and creates a happy mood. However, as the cyclist rides on, the terrain changes; the flat road is replaced by short, rolling hills. At this point, the cyclist is short on water and extremely tired, which crushes their spirit. Riding hills is difficult, especially without the promise of something good on the other side. These two very different settings evoke contrasting feelings. The first makes one think the cyclist will have an easy and enjoyable bike ride, but this changes when they encounter the hills. The mere thought of riding over miles of hills can make one's legs ache. Overall, the features of the setting suggest an intense bike ride for the cyclist, followed by a reward in a beautiful place.

The author had to cycle in extremely hot weather, which made them sweat profusely. As the narration states, “Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt” (@NUM1). This led the author to drink water until the supply ran out, as described by “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips” (@NUM1). In desperation, the author resorted to sucking on pebbles, a risky act as they could have choked. The narration “With any luck I’d hit a bump and lodge one in my throat” (@NUM1) highlights this danger. In conclusion, the hot weather created a series of difficult and dangerous situations for the author during the bike ride.

In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit”, numerous features of the setting affected the cyclist. The most challenging issue the author faced was the lack of water. As described, “I pumped that handle for several minutes but the water wouldn’t come out; when I got a drip or two, it had the flavor of battery acid.” When the cyclist set out for the next stretch, they came across a road sign that read “Rough road ahead, Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” The terrain became bumpier and harder to cross, which affected the cyclist's remaining determination. The cyclist regretted not listening to the old men, thinking they didn't know what they were talking about because they never left their porches. Evidently, the setting affected the cyclist both physically and mentally.

The features of the setting have an impact on the cyclist. One way is through the heat, as stated in the text “I could drop from heat stroke on a gorgeous day in June” @CAPS1. Another way is the bumpy terrain, as indicated by the sign “ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT.” These elements of the setting, heat and bumpy roads, clearly affect the cyclist's experience during the ride. In conclusion, the setting plays a crucial role in influencing the cyclist's journey.

The setting's features have a significant impact on the cyclist as he travels from the desert to a town. His mood and actions are influenced throughout the journey. For instance, when an old man asks for a map, the cyclist's mood shifts. He first becomes cautious on a new road, then experiences terror as he fears for his life, thinking “I was gonna die and the birds would pick me clean”. Later, he feels pride when he tells the old man “I own a very good map”. As he heads towards Yosemite, the setting changes. He passes through a desert - like area and stops at a bait shop to rest before continuing on his way to his destination. Overall, the setting plays a crucial role in shaping the cyclist's experiences during his journey.

In 'Do Not Exceed the Posted Speed Limit' by Joe Kurmaskie, it is evident that the setting's features had a substantial impact on the cyclist. The cyclist was traveling through the desert on a bicycle. Had they been in a car or on a bus, significantly less energy would have been expended. Additionally, the cyclist started to run out of water. Since they were on a bike, this lack of water was a major issue as cycling requires proper hydration. The deserted towns also affected the plot. If these towns had not been deserted, the cyclist's journey would have been much easier. In conclusion, these various features of the setting greatly influenced the cyclist's journey.

The features of the setting significantly influence the cyclist's determination to continue. After traveling @NUM1 miles, the cyclist encounters a “ramshackled shed, several rusty bumps, and a corral”. This sight troubles him. In the desert, the water he has tastes like “battery acid”. He describes this experience as “a test for my inner spirit”. The cyclist continues his journey with just a few drops of water, passing through tumbleweeds. Despite the numerous obstacles he faces, he manages to persevere and gains a bit of confidence. Even though his situation is almost unbearable at times, he keeps pushing forward. In the end, the setting presents challenges that the cyclist overcomes, showing his resilience.

Throughout most of the story, the setting has a profound impact on the cyclist. The heat makes him hot and thirsty, and the long - distance travel depletes his energy and increases his need for water. In paragraph @NUM1, the writer describes one of the hills as “long”. This hill wears the cyclist out and drains the remaining energy he has. The nature of the road, whether it is flat or bumpy, and the temperature are key elements of the setting. The combination of these factors in the setting greatly affects the cyclist's physical state and his ability to continue the journey.

The setting can affect the cyclist in numerous ways. The area where the cyclist is seems to be abandoned. Moreover, the temperature limits the cyclist's water supply, and the risk of complete dehydration is a major concern. All these conditions of the setting put the cyclist at a disadvantage. In conclusion, the setting's features create a challenging environment for the cyclist's journey.

The cyclist had to face various settings, including mountains or hills with winding roads and the California desert in June. Moreover, he was running out of water. These challenging conditions presented significant difficulties for the cyclist during his journey.

In my opinion, the features of the setting have an impact on the cyclist. When the setting is not right, it affects the overall experience. These features could be adjusted slightly without changing the core meaning of the essay. Therefore, I firmly believe that they should be modified to enhance the overall effect.

The features of the setting significantly affect the cyclist. He is undertaking a bike ride through the deserts of California in June. This setting is bound to have an impact on him due to the extreme heat. At one point, he remarks, “The sun was beginning to beat down, but I barely noticed.” Additionally, the presence of numerous ghost towns troubles him as he is alone and starting to run out of water. The weather starts to take a toll on him, and he says, “I wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn’t a mirage…” Cycling through the desert on a hot day inevitably has effects. If the setting were different, the feeling of despair would not be present in the story. This clearly demonstrates how the setting affects the cyclist.

The features of the setting can affect a cyclist in multiple ways. One such feature is the weather. During a cycling trip, the weather can greatly influence the setting. For instance, if it starts to rain, the roads can become slippery and dangerous, increasing the risk of a crash that could endanger the cyclist's life. Another feature is the local animals. Different areas have different animals with various behaviors. Knowing about the animals in the area where the cyclist is traveling can help keep them safe. It is better to be informed and feel secure rather than being unaware of potential dangers.

As the features of the setting change, it becomes increasingly difficult for the cyclist. Initially, the cyclist's journey was relatively easy. He had flat, smooth roads to ride on and started before the sun became too intense. He found solace in the cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite, which helped him stay focused. However, when he reached a highway, the situation became more challenging. The terrain changed from flat roads to short, rolling hills, forcing him to pedal harder and tire more quickly. Later, tumble - weeds crossing his path indicated that he was in the desert during a hot period. With little water left, he became dehydrated, making it extremely difficult for him to maintain his balance. Clearly, the changing terrain made his journey a hard task to overcome.

The setting of the short story “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” is a sweltering, sun - drenched desert where all towns have been deserted. As described, “The sun was beginning to beat down” and “I arrived at the first town it fit the definition of a ghost town”. At this point, the cyclist is neither tired nor overly worried about the lack of water. The setting and the cyclist's state are closely intertwined. This co - existence of the harsh setting and the cyclist's current state sets a unique tone for the story, highlighting the potential challenges that may lie ahead for the cyclist in this desolate environment.

In the story, the cyclist faces numerous challenges. To complete the race, he endures a series of hardships. He must be vigilant on the rough road he traverses. Throughout the race, he also has to watch out for diamond - back snakes. The most pressing issue for the cyclist is water; he runs out of it quickly. When he spots a factory and stops, he puts rocks in his mouth to distract himself from the thirst and to keep his saliva circulating. By persevering through all these problems, the cyclist demonstrates remarkable determination. His ability to overcome these obstacles shows that he is driven and resolute in achieving his goal of finishing the race.

The characteristics of the setting significantly impact the cyclist. He is cycling on a route about which he has little confidence that it will lead anywhere. Having never been on this road before and possessing only outdated information, the cyclist is filled with unease. The temperature is extremely high, with little shade and the sun beating down on him. The route is demoralizing, constantly taunting the cyclist with false hopes of finding water. At the first town, he notices a water pump, but all he can obtain is sludge and water that tastes like battery acid. Later, he comes across a deserted old building that turns out to be an old bottling factory for Welch's grape juice. Each time, the cyclist seems to be close to getting something to drink but is ultimately left empty - handed. These repeated disappointments due to the setting make the cyclist's journey even more arduous.

During the cyclist's bike ride, the unbearable conditions transform his attitude. At the start, the reader can sense his frustration because of the directions given by the old - timers. However, when he realizes that he might have enough water, his attitude begins to change. He shifts from being frustrated to appreciating the scenery, stating, “The cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite had my name written all over them”. But as the conditions deteriorate into even more unbearable heat, he decides to give up. Then, he gathers the courage to continue, “slowly gaining elevation while losing hope”. Finally, when he sees Gary and Wilber's fish camp, he realizes he is safe. This journey through changing attitudes shows how the external conditions can have a profound impact on a person's mental state during a challenging endeavor.

The cyclist in “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Speed Limit” is affected in multiple ways by the environment. The most prominent environmental feature is the lack of water. The cyclist is on the verge of death due to severe dehydration. Another significant factor is the heat. The area where the cyclist is biking is extremely hot, and the heat further dehydrates him, pushing him to his limits. Moreover, the deserted towns haunt him; he becomes frustrated with the lodgers he talks to. The road also poses challenges as the smooth flat terrain gives way to rolling hills, making it more difficult for him to ride. Additionally, he has to avoid a snake on the road. All these environmental factors combined have a substantial impact on the cyclist, making his journey a struggle filled with obstacles.

Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit" by Joe Kurmaskie is a classic tale of man versus nature. A lone cyclist, accompanied only by his bike, the barren landscape, and the unrelenting sun, embarks on a challenging journey. First, the sun beats down overhead, a typical occurrence in a California June but no less oppressive. Then, the rolling hills and inclines come into play. As he pedals uphill, his body works harder, burning calories and depleting his precious water supply. Adding to his torture is the posted speed limit of @NUM1, while he struggles to maintain a speed of just 12. To make matters worse, a billboard shows a young boy pouring a refreshing glass of juice into his mouth, a cruel reminder of what he lacks. Every element of his surroundings contributes to his sense of hopelessness, making this a harrowing account of a man's battle against the forces of nature.

The features of the setting had a significant impact on the cyclist. The road conditions were terrible. The cyclist also encountered a huge snake blocking his path and the occasional tumbleweed. However, the most significant factors affecting the cyclist were the lack of water, the unbearable heat, and his fatigue. These aspects of the setting combined to make the cyclist's journey extremely challenging.

If I had to choose between cycling in California and Vermont, it would be an easy decision to pick Vermont. The temperature in Vermont is much cooler than in California. In the story, the cyclist complains about the "wide rings of dried sweat" and the risk of heatstroke. It is well - known that as temperatures rise, the body loses more water. Had the cyclist chosen a cooler location at a different time of year, he would not have faced dehydration during his bike ride. Clearly, the cooler climate of Vermont would make for a more pleasant cycling experience.

The features of the setting in the story had a profound impact on the cyclist. In the morning, when he started his trip, he was full of eagerness and determination to reach his destination. It took him forty miles to reach the first "town," but he didn't seem to mind. As the sun began to beat down, he thought about the cool pines and rushing rivers of Yosemite, showing that he was unfazed at that time. However, as the trip progressed, the heat increased, and his water supply dwindled. After passing a couple of abandoned and desolate "troubling sights," he started to worry. In his desperation, he resorted to sucking on pebbles to keep the last bit of spit in his mouth. Finally, he saw a sign of hope that gave him the strength to continue. When he arrived at GARY AND @CAPS1'S FISH CAMP, his mood changed from despair to gratitude, highlighting how the setting's features influenced his emotional and physical state throughout the journey.

During his cycling trip, author and cyclist Joe Kurmaskie had to face numerous challenges related to the setting of Yosemite National Park. He endured extreme heat, encountered snakes, had little to no shade, and suffered from a severe lack of water. He became dehydrated, as he described, "the sun was beginning to beat down and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June." One of his struggles was crossing the path of a "ridiculously large snake" while trying to maintain his balance in a dehydrated state. Due to the extreme heat, he ran out of water. When he reached a water pump, he found the water unfit for drinking and extremely hot. Another issue related to the setting was that the area seemed deserted, and he had to cycle for miles before finding a place with clean water where he could rest and rehydrate. Overall, the setting of Yosemite National Park presented a series of difficult obstacles for Kurmaskie during his cycling trip.

In the story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the setting's features significantly impacted the cyclist. The presence of rolling hills made pedaling a challenge. Additionally, tumbleweeds obstructed the cyclist's path; if caught on the bike, they could cause the cyclist to fall and sustain injuries. Moreover, the rough road ahead, with potholes and other obstacles, made riding difficult. Overall, the setting had a notable adverse effect on the cyclist.

The features of the setting continuously affect the cyclist. Initially, he is hopeful, but then realizes the situation is hopeless. He laughed when people gave him the right directions, yet later, as he referred back to the first town, he said, “It was sad, hopeless laughter, mind you, but at least I still had energy to feel bad for myself.” At first, the cyclist was doing well, but then he got thirsty and encountered bad things. In conclusion, these elements of the setting clearly influenced the cyclist's state and journey.

In Joe Kurmaskie's story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the setting's features had multiple effects on the author. One prominent feature was the hills. In summary, the setting, including the hills and the speed - limit, had a notable impact on the author's experience in the story.

The setting affects the cyclist in several ways. The hot, dry heat of the California desert makes him hot and thirsty, leading to a shortage of water. In conclusion, the setting has a profound and multi - faceted effect on the cyclist.

The cyclist was significantly affected by the features of the setting as he was in a desert. There were no stores, rivers, or lakes. The setting's features significantly impact the cyclist. Key elements such as the pseudo - towns that are now dilapidated and the water pump play crucial roles. But despite trying to pump water for several minutes, as he said, "I pumped the handle for several minutes but the water wouldnít cool down." The features of the setting have a notable impact on the cyclist. The features of the road have a direct impact on the cyclist. When the road has a downhill slope, the cyclist can ride at a faster speed. Conversely, an uphill road forces the cyclist to slow down. Moreover, the road may have obstacles such as bumpy rocks or patches of grass, which make cycling difficult. In essence, the cyclist's experience is highly dependent on the road's construction. The nature of the road, whether it is smooth or full of obstacles, determines the cyclist's speed and the effort required to pedal.

The features of the setting have a profound effect on the cyclist's desire for water. As the conditions of the setting deteriorate, the cyclist's thirst intensifies. For example, in the essay, tumbleweeds crossing the path and a large snake blocking the pavement are described. Tumbleweeds are associated with dryness, like dry grass, and snakes are often seen when it is hot. These elements made the cyclist acutely aware of the dryness in his throat and surroundings, increasing his craving for water. Another feature was a sandblasted picture of a young boy drinking a glass of juice. This image likely made the cyclist long for a cold, refreshing drink. In "Rough Road ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit", the cyclist was negatively affected by various features of the setting. First, the old men gave her a "shortcut" on her journey to Yosemite National Park, which may have led her astray. In the short - story “Rough Road Ahead”, the cyclist encounters numerous problems, and the setting plays a significant role. The story is set in a desert, an extremely hot environment with no water sources and scarce human habitation. The cyclist is running out of water, as the text states, “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips.” Additionally, the story takes place in June, a very hot month. When combined with the desert setting, this extreme heat poses a severe challenge to the cyclist. The settings have a notable impact on a cyclist's performance. When the weather is too hot, the sun beats down on the cyclist, which can cause them to slow down. Conversely, in cold weather, cyclists need to wear more clothes, which may add weight and prevent them from achieving the desired speed. The condition of the bike is also crucial. It should be stable, and factors such as riding on rough roads, proper braking, smooth speeding, and well - maintained chains are important. The area where the cyclist rides sets the mood. A nice scenery can put the cyclist in a wonderful mood, while a dark, gloomy area with bad weather can have the opposite effect. These aspects collectively determine how settings can influence a cyclist's experience.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead”, the setting has a profound impact on the cyclists. The desert climate bears down on the cyclist. For instance, the route the cyclist takes is not only in a desert but also lacks water sources. The combination of intense heat and the lack of water leads to a high risk of deadly dehydration for the cyclists. As a result, the setting compels the cyclist to be more determined if they want to survive. They must continue their journey and hope to come across a town where they can restock on water and rehydrate. The harsh setting thus becomes a significant challenge that the cyclist must overcome.

On the cyclist's way to Yosemite National Park, many factors influenced his journey, but the environment he was in had the most significant impact. He was in a dry desert area where tumbleweeds were more common than people. When the cyclist met some old men and asked for directions, they led him to a “ghost town”. There was no water for the dehydrated cyclist who had been exposed to the extremely dry and hot weather. This made the cyclist fear that he would die in the desert due to the weather, the wrong directions, and the lack of water. However, when he came across a bait shop, he knew he was saved. He rehydrated and declined directions from an old man because the elements of the setting, such as the old men, the dry weather, and the lack of water, had caused his problems in the first place.

In the story, several factors affect the cyclist. One major issue is dehydration. The text describes the situation as “The water bottle contained only a few tantalizing sips. Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from heat stroke on a gorgeous day in June.” On the positive side, the absence of other people on the road allowed the cyclist to ride without being slowed down. However, there were negative impacts too. Taking directions from some gentlemen who hadn't left their porch in a decade led to problems. Also, a poisonous snake got in the cyclist's way. The text mentions, “At some point, tumble weeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake -- It really did look like a diamond back. Blocked the major of the pavement in front of me.” These various factors combined to create a challenging journey for the cyclist.

A cyclist, unsure of his destination, received incorrect information and followed it. He was initially excited, thinking he knew where he was going. During his journey, he was affected by various elements. The sun was a major factor; the intense heat in the summer made him dehydrated, and he was running out of water, which made the journey extremely difficult and put him in a strange mood. Additionally, he encountered a large snake, which startled him as he feared an attack and was unsure how to proceed. Due to his lack of knowledge about the route and his unpreparedness for the hot weather on a bicycle, he ended up going in the wrong direction. In conclusion, the combination of misinformation, harsh environmental conditions, and unexpected encounters significantly hindered the cyclist's journey.

The features of the setting have a notable impact on the cyclist's state of mind. On page @NUM1, the cyclist mentions, “I had been hitting my water bottles pretty regularly, and I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” This description creates a sense of the intense heat and foreshadows a potential water shortage later. As he passes a snake, he struggles to maintain balance in his dehydrated state, likely feeling dizzy and starting to lose hope. On page @NUM2, he says, “…I could drop from heatstroke…,” indicating that he is imagining the worst - case scenarios. By page @NUM3, he laments, “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean…,” showing that the harsh conditions have made him extremely worried and caused him to lose hope. In summary, the setting's features, including the heat and isolation, had a detrimental effect on the cyclist throughout the story.

The setting presented numerous challenges for the cyclist due to the limited water supply. Joe @PERSON1 described the desolate environment, stating, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind.” The absence of people or nearby stores made it difficult for the cyclist to get proper directions after receiving bad ones from a few old men. @PERSON1 also recounted, “working the handle of the rusted water pump with all my strength,” highlighting the struggle to find water, which led to weakness and instability. Moreover, the terrain changed from flat roads to short, rolling hills, which was arduous for a cyclist with little water and a weakened body. Additionally, traveling through the high deserts of California in June meant dealing with dust in the lungs and the sun's intense heat, further straining the body. In conclusion, the setting's lack of resources and harsh conditions severely hampered the cyclist's journey.

The setting in the story has a significant impact on the cyclist. The story is set in June, and the extreme heat causes the cyclist to become severely dehydrated. The description “wiped the sweat from my eyes to make sure it wasn't a mirage” gives a vivid sense of the sweltering conditions. The cyclist also implies that it felt like two hundred degrees as the sun beat down. The heat and dehydration made the cyclist's journey extremely challenging. In conclusion, the hot and arid setting in June in California had a detrimental effect on the cyclist's physical and mental state during the journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in multiple ways. In June, while traveling through the @CAPS1 of California, the intense heat dehydrated him. Since he was unsure of his route, he had to rely on the directions of others. The lack of water and the continuous dehydration further exacerbated his situation. These factors combined to make his journey difficult and uncertain. In conclusion, the combination of the hot weather, unfamiliarity with the route, and dehydration significantly affected the cyclist's experience.

In Joe Kurmaskie's essay “Do Not Exceed the Posted Speed Limit,” the settings presented a rough and challenging environment. A solo cyclist rode through Todi, California, an arduous area for cycling. The long and hot ride left him severely dehydrated, with dried sweat around his neck. The cyclist reported seeing no one, no buildings, cars, or structures. He had no access to water or food as the area was deserted. He even contemplated that if he died, no one would find him before the birds picked his body clean. This essay portrays solo cyclists as highly independent individuals.

In Joe Kurmaskie's story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the cyclist encountered numerous obstacles. He needed directions to Yosemite National Park, but the directions from the elder men were outdated. At a fork in the road, he had to make a choice and selected a path that the old men said would lead to a town about eighteen miles ahead. Additionally, he faced flat roads that transitioned to rolling hills, snakes blocking his way, and a state of dehydration that could have been fatal. In the end, the cyclist overcame these obstacles to reach Yosemite National Park.

In Joe Kurmaskie's essay “Rough Road Ahead Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the setting impacts the cyclist in multiple ways. Initially, he followed the advice of an old man and ended up on the wrong path. It was a hot June day in the California deserts. The cyclist's situation was dire from the start; as Kurmaskie wrote, “The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips, wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I needed a drop from heatstroke on a gorgeous day in June…” This shows that he was tired and nearly out of water. Despite the significant strain on the cyclist, he managed to persevere.

The setting has a substantial impact on the cyclist. Flat roads are easy and smooth for cycling, but when the road changes to short, rolling hills, the cycling becomes more difficult. The sentence “Over are long, crippling hill...” supports this, indicating that the hill is a challenging obstacle. The cyclist is also affected by the elements that come with the terrain change. For instance, the description “...tumbleweeds crossed my path and a ridiculously large snake it really did look like a diamondbuck - looked the majority of the pavement in front of me” emphasizes the remoteness of the area. This remoteness has both mental and physical effects on his cycling trip.

Two old - timers sitting on their front porch in the desert since Carter was in office set the scene. As daylight began to break, the cyclist had to walk @NUM1 miles to reach the next town. He then got on his bike and started riding. The speed limit was 55 miles per hour, but he was going at a mere 12 miles per hour, as slow as a gentle water flow. He cycled up and down rolling hills. Eventually, he reached the next town, ensuring his survival.

The setting's characteristics had an impact on the cyclist as he got lost after asking the elderly for directions. This shows that the setting, through the interaction with local people, presented challenges for the cyclist.

In the essay, the setting's features significantly affected the cyclist. The author depicts the setting as hot and bumpy, causing the cyclist to sweat and become tired. He is also running out of water due to thirst. At one point, the road turns very rocky, as the narrator states, “Flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). A photograph further illustrates the rough terrain, which is barren with nothing around. Overall, these aspects of the setting had a substantial impact on the cyclist's journey.

The features of the setting affect the cyclist in multiple ways. The cyclist is dehydrated and has to ride on a road with poor conditions, along with the presence of snakes and hills. These elements act as obstacle - courses, making it difficult for him to obtain water. Due to the heat and lack of water, the cyclist is delirious and may not know what is happening. In the story, the main feature of the setting is the road, as described by “Rough road ahead.” Riding on a rough road while dehydrated is extremely dangerous. These features of the setting clearly have a negative impact on the cyclist.

The settings have a significant impact on the cyclist. When he first arrives at the “@CAPS1 town,” he is not overly worried; he even chuckles and makes a light - hearted comment, “This place might have been a thriving little spot at one time - say, before the last world war.” However, when it gets dark on the road with the risky water pipe, he switches to a conservation mode and becomes scared. He says, “I would comer water - a test at my inner spirit,” indicating his fear. After seeing the abandoned Grape juice factory, he remarks that birds will pick him clean, leaving behind his expensive biking gear, showing that he is giving up. This is further supported by his mention of writing in his diary about the old men who gave him directions. When he finally reaches the bait shop, he is relieved, goes to the bathroom to drink water, and says he will buy bait even though he has no rod. These instances clearly demonstrate how the setting affected the cyclist.

In the story “Do not exceed posted speed limit,” the features of the setting impact the cyclist. On a hot summer day, finding shade is necessary to keep cool, but unfortunately, there is no one in sight, no building, car, or any structure. This lack of shade only makes the cyclist more exhausted. Another factor is the lack of water; early in the story, the author mentions that “The water bottle contained only a few tantalizing sips.” With many miles still to go, the cyclist starts to lose hope of reaching his destination alive. The rolling hills also affect the cyclist. Although the hills are short, they still have an impact on him as “flat roads was replaced by short, rolling hills.” Evidently, many features of the story influenced the mood and the cyclist's experience.

The setting's features had an impact on the cyclist. As the distance showed @NUM1 miles and he reached the first town, the cyclist grew excited, thinking he was almost done and moving at a fast pace. When he arrived at the town, it appeared deserted. As he continued, he realized he wasn't making much progress. He then recalled that he had listened to some old folks who had never left their porch. After reaching the first town, he knew he should never listen to old folks again because the town seemed to have been empty for years.

The features of the setting on the journey to Yosemite National Park significantly affected the cyclist. While traveling to the park, the cyclist experienced the intense heat of the California desert. Additionally, he had to navigate the rough terrain of the short, rolling hills, which made him tired and fatigued. Compounding his weakness and the extreme heat, he ran out of water, leading to dehydration. As he put it, “Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt, and the growing realization that I could drop from a heat - stroke... laugh.” This passage through the California desert caused great exhaustion and dehydration for the cyclist, clearly demonstrating the impact of the setting.

The features of the setting can have a substantial impact on a cyclist. The climate may be hot, the road bumpy, and the town deserted. For instance, a sign reading “Rough Road Ahead. Do not exceed posted speed limit” poses a challenge for a thirsty cyclist. Without water, it would be difficult for the cyclist to climb the hills. Moreover, if there is no town nearby to get water, the cyclist will suffer from thirst. The so - called “first town” might have once been a lively place, but it now resembles a ghost town with no water available. In conclusion, these setting features can make a cyclist's journey extremely difficult.

The features of the setting affected the cyclist in three main ways: heat, lack of water, and getting lost. Firstly, the heat was intense. The cyclist mentioned that the sun was beating down, the water felt around two - hundred degrees, and he was covered in sweat, indicating just how hot it was. Secondly, the lack of water affected his performance. He was desperately in need of water and tried various means to obtain it, but managed to continue with hardly any water. Thirdly, he got lost as the map he had was inaccurate, and the trip did not turn out as he expected. However, in the end, he felt relieved. Despite these negative impacts, he managed to find a positive outcome. This story shows that if you try your hardest, never give up, and are willing to try new things, you are likely to succeed in life and other endeavors. So, one should always strive to do their best and make the most of their life and plans.

The conditions a cyclist encounters can either be obstacles or aids. For example, a rocky uphill section will undoubtedly slow the cyclist down. On the other hand, a smooth downhill part will increase the cyclist's speed and reduce the effort required for pedaling. In conclusion, the nature of the cycling conditions plays a crucial role in determining the cyclist's speed and the amount of work they need to put in.

In June, a cyclist found himself in the California deserts. The extreme environment started to wear him down, and he began to lose hope. Adding to his despair, a rusty water pump provided water that tasted like battery acid. When he saw the sign “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” he became extremely cautious. He was certain that he would die there. The text also mentions that “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind,” which made him feel incredibly lonely. Being in the California desert, he was convinced that death awaited him.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit” by Joe Kurmaskie, the author details his arduous biking journey through California. He states, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June.” Although this doesn't directly describe the weather, it allows readers to envision the intense summer heat of a desert. As the author encounters a “ghost town,” a dilapidated shack, and finally the sign reading “Rough Road Ahead,” his hope of reaching Yosemite Park vanishes. The hopelessness of the situation makes him want to give up, fearing death from dehydration and exhaustion in the desert. This experience can resonate with anyone who has been lost in unfavorable circumstances and felt the accompanying helplessness and fear. Just as it seems everything is against you with nothing going your way, the author captures this feeling in his account of the trip.

The setting had a significant impact on the cyclist. The exhaustion began to take its toll on him. Compounding the problem, being out in the heat made him sweat, leading to dehydration. In such a situation, the combination of physical fatigue and water loss severely affected the cyclist's well - being.

One of the features that affected the cyclist was a lack of water. This is evident when the speaker mentions that when they tried a drop or two of the available water, it tasted like battery acid. This poor - quality water was one of the major risks the cyclist faced during his journey. Overall, the scarcity and unpalatability of water had a detrimental impact on his situation.

As the reader followed the old - timers' directions, they encountered numerous issues and learned a lesson. At the start of the morning ride, they had strong legs and a smile on their face. However, as time passed, they were running out of water and energy. The hot summer day made them sweat profusely, and they started to imagine that birds would peck at their body if they died on the way to Yosemite. When they finally reached a town, they refreshed themselves. They then realized that they should start following their own way of getting to places, learning from this challenging experience.

In the essay “Do not exceed the posted speed limit,” the characteristics of the setting had a detrimental impact on the cyclist. As he continued his ride, his thoughts became increasingly negative, and he was filled with doubt. Lacking confidence, he began to believe he would not complete the journey. For instance, when he saw nothing in the vicinity, his tone changed. He noted, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structure of any kind. I began breaking the ride down into distances I could see on the horizon, telling myself that if I could make it that far, I’d be fine.” His words revealed uncertainty and a touch of nervousness. As the journey progressed, it seemed the cyclist was losing hope. He thought, “It didn’t really matter. I was going to die, and the birds would pick me clean, leaving only some expensive outdoor gear and a diary.” With no end in sight and only “Rough Road Ahead” signs to accompany him, he struggled to envision finishing the journey. In conclusion, the setting’s features significantly undermined the cyclist’s confidence and hope during his ride.

The setting features presented numerous challenges to the cyclist. He found himself in a desert region of California, where the water supply was scarce. The weather was extremely hot and dry, and he had very little water to sustain him through the long journey in the sweltering and humid conditions. The lack of water put him at risk of dehydration. Another obstacle was the hills he encountered on his biking trip to Yosemite National Park. Initially on flat terrain, he now had to pedal up steep hills, which made the journey much more arduous. Additionally, he came across a snake, further complicating his trip. Overall, the setting was fraught with difficulties for the cyclist. Had it not been for the heat and water shortage, his journey might have been less challenging. In conclusion, the setting’s features posed significant obstacles that tested the cyclist’s endurance and ability to overcome adversity.

The setting’s features had a profound impact on the cyclist. The rolling hills were the most formidable challenge, as they were long and demanding. Maneuvering up these hills required a great deal of energy and determination, especially considering the cyclist was already fatigued from riding on rough roads and encountering a large snake. The difficult terrain also contributed to his risk of dehydration and heatstroke, as the physical exertion in the hot conditions took a toll on his body. However, the cyclist maintained a positive attitude and refused to give up. His perseverance paid off when he finally reached “Gary and Wilbells fish camp,” where he likely found relief. In conclusion, the setting’s features forced the cyclist to work extremely hard, but his determination allowed him to overcome these challenges and continue his journey.

In the short story “Do not exceed posted speed limit,” the features of the setting have a notable impact on the cyclist. As the road and setting change, so does the cyclist’s mood. The narration describes, “A large highway sign jumped out at me. I read: Rough road ahead: Do not exceed posted speed limit … sometimes life can feel so cruel (Kurmaskie).” As the terrain becomes more difficult, the cyclist’s spirits decline. Each time he thinks he is approaching a town, his hopes are quickly dashed. The picture depicts the challenging cycling terrain, which, combined with a lack of water and a growing sense of hopelessness, makes the cyclist tired and leads him to believe he might die. In conclusion, the setting’s features significantly affect the cyclist’s physical and mental state, making his journey a struggle.

Certain features of the setting influenced the cyclist’s ride. One such feature was the speed - limit signs, which affected the cyclist’s speed. Another was a hill on the route. The cyclist’s statement, “I wipe the sweat from my eyes,” indicates that the hill made him tired. In conclusion, the speed - limit signs and the hill in the setting had a direct impact on the cyclist’s speed and physical exertion during the ride.

The setting significantly influenced the cyclist. Firstly, the area he was in, a desert, had a severe water shortage. Moreover, the scarcity of people in the region offered no assistance to the cyclist. The hills on the road further challenged the cyclist as they depleted the little energy he had left. Additionally, the intense sunlight made his body overheat, making it difficult for him to concentrate on his task. In conclusion, the harsh setting posed multiple obstacles for the cyclist, severely hampering his progress.

In the setting where a sign reads “Rough road ahead: do not exceed posted speed limit,” the cyclist is profoundly affected. Initially, the cyclist was enjoying a pleasant campground outside Lodi, California. At that time, some “old - timers” provided him with directions. From the cyclist's perspective, “they'd sounded so sure of themselves when pointing out landmarks and naming towns I would come across along this breezy route.” The cyclist followed this information, but it did not turn out well for him. In conclusion, relying on the old - timers' directions led to an unfavorable situation for the cyclist.

The features of the setting had a notable impact on the cyclist. When an old guy asked another if he knew where to go, the latter replied, “Yes sir! I own a very good map.” As the cyclist rode his bike, he saw numerous towns and a sign that said “Rough Road ahead.” He kept moving forward, passing by buildings and towns. It seems that his experience of seeing these things might make him more inclined to look towards the future. In conclusion, the setting and the events during his journey could potentially change the cyclist's outlook and make him more future - oriented.

In the story, the cyclist encountered numerous problems. One of the most significant issues was the challenging terrain he had to navigate. The hilly landscape was extremely tiring; cycling uphill consumes more energy and wears a person out faster compared to riding on flat land. The unbearable heat also made it difficult for him to focus. The cyclist did his best to stay conscious while traversing the hilly and deserted landscape of a vast desert with rolling mountains. He pushed forward but found no civilization to refill his water. For instance, if the terrain had been less hilly, he would have used less energy and put less strain on his legs. The intense desert heat likely slowed his progress. Heat generally makes one move slower, and cycling on a barren road with no shade can make the journey seem endless and impossible. In the end, his willpower and determination enabled him to cross the landscape and reach a place where he could get the water he needed to complete his trip.

In this essay, the features of the setting made the cyclist irritated with the old men. The old men gave the cyclist directions, and instead of using a map, he followed their advice. However, the information they provided was outdated. It led the cyclist through rolling hills and bumpy roads. He exhausted all his energy to reach unimportant and unknown towns without any water. The cyclist blamed the old men for giving him directions that wasted his energy. But in fact, he should also blame himself for taking their advice instead of relying on a reliable map for accurate directions. In conclusion, the cyclist's poor decision of following the old men's advice and not using a map led to a frustrating and energy - consuming journey.

The setting where one is cycling significantly influences the cyclist. In my view, the setting is the most crucial aspect. It sets the tone and context for the entire cycling experience, making it an indispensable factor.

In Joe Kurmaskie's short story “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the setting has a profound impact on the cyclist's mindset. When the scenery is pleasant and cheerful, as described by the author's mention of “enjoyed the serenity of an early - summer - evening,” the cyclist is happy. One can infer happiness from the word “enjoyed,” as people typically enjoy things when they are in a positive state of mind. Conversely, when the author writes, “At some point, tumble weeds crossed my path and the growing realization that I could drop from heatstroke,” the desolate scenery with tumbleweeds, which are stereotypically associated with dreary and lonely places, makes the cyclist pessimistic. He starts focusing on all that could go wrong. This phenomenon is observable in daily life; for example, the poor and homeless with a low standard of living often have a negative outlook. In conclusion, the setting significantly affects the cyclist's mindset.

The cyclist is affected by the features of the setting due to its drastic changes. The initially flat and wide - open road transformed into “short, rolling hills.” With his water supply running out, it became increasingly difficult for him to muster the willpower and determination to navigate these hills. As he started seeing vast open lands filled with “tumbleweeds and ridiculously large snakes,” his determination waned. The scorching sun and lack of water made him fear dehydration. To cope, he put pebbles in his mouth to stimulate saliva. In his despair, he even wished to choke on a pebble as he felt utterly useless. In summary, the changing setting severely tested the cyclist's physical and mental endurance.

In Joe Kurmaskie's “Do not exceed posted speed limit,” the cyclist encounters numerous hardships on his journey to Yosemite because of the setting. The hot summer day exacerbated his difficulties. With limited water, he was prone to dehydration. As the author states, “I could drop from heat stroke, on a gorgeous day in June” (Kurmaskie, @NUM1), highlighting the danger of the June heat. Moreover, there were few people around, mainly “Old timers who haven’t left the confines of their perches since water was in offing” (Kurmaskie, @NUM2). The narrator doubts the reliability of their directions as they seem out - of - date and incorrect. Overall, the setting made the cyclist's journey to his destination extremely arduous.

In Joe Kurmaskie's “Do not exceed posted speed limit,” the cyclist faces multiple difficulties due to the terrain. He was already short on water from the strenuous journey, and then the environment turned against him. As the narration indicates, “I noticed the terrain changing; flat road was replaced by short, rolling hills” (Kurmaskie @NUM1). This means the cyclist has to expend more energy to climb these hills, energy that he scarcely has. It will nearly deplete his remaining energy. Additionally, the mention of “At some point, tumbleweeds crossed my path” (Kurmaskie @NUM1) shows that the cyclist is in a desolate area with limited water and energy, further compounding his problems. In conclusion, the setting in the story led to numerous challenges for the cyclist.

In the story “Rough Road Ahead,” the setting has a significant impact on the cyclist. The cyclist faces challenges such as a shortage of water, the long distance to be covered, and the hilly terrain. The statement “The water bottles contain only a few tantalizing sips. Wide rings of dried sweat circled my shirt” indicates that the cyclist is out of water and is exhausted and hot. Clearly, the setting in the story greatly affects the cyclist.

The cyclist encounters difficulties due to the conditions of lack of water, heat, and rough terrain, all of which make the ride more arduous. Firstly, the shortage of water depletes the energy he needs to continue. Secondly, the heat also impacts his journey, making it extremely difficult for him to keep going; he even fears for his life, imagining birds pecking at his dead body. Finally, the terrain does not help either. The route has numerous hills, which consume a great deal of energy and thus make the trip harder. In conclusion, these factors work against the cyclist.

Here, I will explain how the cyclist is affected. One factor is that the heat makes him drink more water, causing him to run out. Another is that some misleading old guys give him wrong directions. Additionally, the long distance and poor terrain slow him down. Lastly, a snake also slows him down. In sum, these are the elements that have a negative impact on the cyclist's journey.

The characteristics of the setting influence the cyclist in multiple ways. He is cycling across an area where there are no cars, no people, no water, and no food. This journey is fraught with danger for him, yet he manages to complete it. In conclusion, the challenging setting presents difficulties but the cyclist overcomes them.

The features of the setting do exert an influence on the cyclist. For instance, the condition of his jar is one such factor that affects him. In conclusion, the setting features, like the jar's condition, have an impact on the cyclist.

The features of the setting can influence a cyclist. For instance, an empty setting might trigger the urge to go faster and unleash one's inner need for speed. However, personally, I believe the setting where one rides a bike is not significant. It might matter to some bicyclists, but in my view, it holds little importance.

The cyclist was significantly affected by the features of the setting. As he cycled, there were no cars, buildings, water, or people in sight. The road transitioned from flat to rolling hills. Despite having no water, he was determined to keep pedaling. When he saw a sign warning of a rough road ahead and to not exceed the posted speed - limit, he was in a dire situation as he had run out of water and was in the middle of nowhere. If I were in his shoes, I'd feel hopeless. All he could see were endless rolling hills. When he spotted a building over the hills, he thought he was saved. But upon reaching it, he found it and others to be abandoned, and he thought he was going to die. In conclusion, the desolate setting greatly affected the cyclist. A setting with cars and buildings on either side might have given him confidence, but that was not the case. Finally, he rounded a bend and said, “Then, as easily as rounding a bend my troubles, thirst, and fear were all behind me.”

There are numerous features of the setting that impact the cyclist. His dehydration began when the sun beat down on him, making him extremely thirsty. His situation worsened when he ran out of water and passed an abandoned Welch's grape - juice factory. He saw a sand - blasted picture of a young boy pouring a glass of juice into his mouth and hung his head. When he was almost out of strength, he spotted a bait shop. He said, “Somehow I climbed away from the abandoned factory of juices and dreams, slowly gaining elevation while losing hope.” Then, as easily as rounding a bend, his troubles, thirst, and fear were behind him. When he saw “Gary and [CAPS2] Fish camp – If you want bait for the big ones, we're your best bet,” his troubles were resolved.

The features of the setting through which the author cycled have a profound impact on both his mood and physical condition. Firstly, the author is in “the high deserts of California in June,” which implies that the hot weather causes him to sweat while cycling. Subsequently, there is a change in terrain as he approaches “rolling hills,” which are more challenging to bike on. Finally, the author sees a sign reading “ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT.” He becomes discouraged because his bike cannot reach the speed limit, yet he still has to navigate the rough road. After passing this road, he sees a picture of a boy drinking juice on a juice factory. This sight likely intensifies his thirst and leaves him more exhausted and frustrated than before. Clearly, the features of his surroundings play a substantial role in the author's mood change.

The setting features have a substantial impact on the cyclist. The blistering sun is a major factor. The intense heat dehydrates him and nearly causes his demise. The rocky road also takes a toll, consuming his time and energy. The desert setting compounds his problems; there is no one to offer assistance, and no place to obtain water. In conclusion, the setting is a crucial element in this story as it significantly influences the cyclist's experience and well - being.

In the essay “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the setting presents significant challenges for the cyclist. The cyclist traversed a desert under extremely humid conditions with no access to water. Along the way, he encountered poisonous snakes and areas devoid of buildings or any form of civilization. These elements of the setting formed the main conflict in the essay. During parts of the journey, the cyclist had no water and lost all hope, believing it was futile. As stated in the story, “It didn’t really matter. I was going to die…” The harshness of the setting led the cyclist to lose control, resorting to putting stones in his mouth to distract from his thirst. Overall, the setting had a profound impact on the cyclist, both physically and mentally.

The setting can impact a cyclist in various ways, such as the shape of the road, the need to ride up hills, and the road's roughness. There was a sign that read “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit.” Had the cyclist not seen this sign, he might have exceeded the speed limit or been unaware of the appropriate speed for cycling, potentially resulting in injury. Since the road was designed for cars, adhering to the speed limit can be challenging for cyclists. In conclusion, the road - related aspects of the setting can pose difficulties for cyclists.

In Joe Kurmaskie's “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the setting has a notable impact on the cyclist. The first setting took a toll on him. In this environment, he depleted his water supply in the heat. This made him start to feel dehydrated and fear for his life. The text indicates this when it states “I could drop from heat stroke.” Later, when the cyclist reached an abandoned juice factory, thinking about his thirst made him even more parched and disappointed. The final setting had a positive effect as he finally obtained water and was no longer thirsty. In summary, the different settings throughout the story significantly influenced the cyclist's physical and emotional state.

During that long bike ride, the cyclist was affected by the setting in multiple ways. The lack of water, the heat, and receiving bad directions all took a toll on him. Throughout the journey, the cyclist ran out of water because of the incorrect directions given by some men. As described, “Trying to keep my balance in my dehydrated state. The water bottles contained only a few tantalizing sips.” The heat in the high deserts of California in June also contributed to his dehydration. The author mentions, “I was traveling through the high deserts of California in June,” and anyone who has been to California knows it can be extremely hot. Additionally, the wrong directions from some old men extended the trip. The men gave directions that were accurate in their time, but the land had changed. As the cyclist said, “Because I listened to some gentlemen who hadn’t been off their porch in decades, caused me to laugh.” Clearly, the setting of a bike ride can either be a great asset or a significant hindrance, as the cyclist in this story experienced.

The setting exerts a multitude of effects on the biker. In June, he is cycling through the high deserts of California. Summers are naturally hot, and desert heat is twice as intense. This causes the biker to dehydrate rapidly, necessitating more water. The only available water source was an old pump, but the water was so hot and tasted so bad that he couldn't drink it. As Kurmaskie put it, “When I tried a drop it had the flavor of battery acid.” The route was deserted, leaving the biker with no one to turn to for help. Moreover, the terrain was difficult. The hills forced the biker to expend more energy, which was crucial for his survival. He even laughed at the thought of dropping from heatstroke. He also came across dangerous animals like the diamond - black rattlesnake. Mentally, the biker was frustrated with himself for following the directions of old men. He realized he should have taken the correct path instead of the abandoned and dangerous shortcut. In conclusion, the setting impacts the biker both physically and mentally.

The setting's features had a significant impact on the cyclist. The sun started to beat down, and the cyclist regularly reached for their water bottles. The cyclist in this story was incredibly brave. During his journey, he faced numerous obstacles, and nature was clearly against him that day. After getting through the hills, he encountered a sign that read “ROUGH ROAD AHEAD: DO NOT EXCEED POSTED SPEED LIMIT,” meaning he had to navigate bumpy roads next. Then, tumbleweeds crossed his path, and a huge snake, which looked like a diamondback, blocked most of the pavement in front of him. Thankfully, he managed to pass the snake alive. As he climbed over a long, tiring hill, a building came into view. He thought he'd found a place to get water, but it was an abandoned Welch's grape juice factory and bottling plant. In the end, despite all these challenges, his courage got him through this difficult part of the journey.

Nearly all of the cyclist's surroundings are old and barren, with a hot @CAPS1 - like climate. The features of the setting influence the cyclist's confidence in his destination and the means of getting there. The lack of water is a crucial factor that affects his state of mind. If the sun had not been so glaring and the road not so treacherous, the author's journey would have been much easier. When engaging in cycling or any outdoor sport, the setting is of great significance. In cold conditions, a jacket is necessary; in hot conditions, water is essential. The safety of the setting can be a matter of life and death. For example, a hilly terrain can cause fatigue, and without water, one could face a life - threatening situation. Moreover, whether the location is a city suburb, a small town, a desert, or a highway all have a substantial impact on cycling. In conclusion, cyclists and outdoor sports enthusiasts should always consider the setting to ensure their safety and well - being.

In June, a cyclist was in California. The features of the setting had profound effects on him. Due to the hot weather, he needed a large amount of water and was sweating profusely. If the weather had been cooler, his water requirement would have been much lower. Additionally, the absence of buildings and cars meant there was no one around to offer assistance. As the cyclist put it, “There was no one in sight, not a building, car, or structures of any kind.” Clearly, the features of the setting can significantly influence a cyclist's experience and safety.

In Joe Kurmaskie's essay “Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the features of the setting have an impact on the cyclist. The cyclist is cycling “through the high deserts of California in June,” as stated by Kurmaskie. This setting causes the cyclist to dehydrate more quickly. The cyclist, who is also the author, becomes dehydrated before reaching the next town, as evidenced by him “gathering up a few pebbles and sticking them in [his] mouth.” In summary, the setting in this essay plays a crucial role in the cyclist's experience.

In Joe Kurmaskie's essay “Do not exceed posted speed limit,” the surrounding setting had a significant impact on the cyclist. In early summer, the cyclist was outside Lodi, California. Taking advice from some old men led him into difficult situations. As the sun beat down and his water supply dwindled, reaching Yosemite became extremely challenging. Traveling through the high deserts of California in June, when the terrain changed from flat roads to rolling hills, the cyclist pushed himself harder. The sun and hot air dehydrated him rapidly. After crossing a “along, crippling hill,” he stopped and even tried sucking on a pebble to distract from his thirst. When he found an inhabited store, he was exhausted but relieved. The weather dehydrated him and the terrain exhausted him, clearly showing that the features of the setting had a major effect on the cyclist.

I believe the settings in the essay affected the cyclist both mentally and physically. Cycling through the desert in June made his water supply run out quickly. If he had been riding at a different time, say @DATE1, his water would have lasted longer and he would have had more energy. The abandoned town the old men told him about forced him to keep going despite his weakening state. What affected him most, in my opinion, was reaching the bait store. If it had been abandoned like other places, he would have died. Fortunately, it wasn't, and he could drink water. The picture of the boy in the factory haunted him mentally as the boy was drinking juice, something the cyclist couldn't do. Having fainted from dehydration myself, I know the stages well: first, a headache; then, a dry mouth and desperation; finally, dizziness. In conclusion, the conditions the cyclist endured had a huge impact on him.

In the story “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the setting significantly influences the cyclist's physical and mental state, with both positive and negative effects. Physically, the effects of the setting are evident throughout the narrative. For instance, when the cyclist reaches @PERSON2 and @PERSON1’s Fish Camp, he can re - hydrate, which restores his health and safety. Mentally, the setting also has a substantial impact. When the cyclist is in the comfortable camp in @LOCATION1, he feels happy, which prepares him for the trip to Yosemite. However, when he encounters “Ramshackle @CAPS2, several rusty pumps, and a corral,” the limited available water troubles him. Cycling in the dry, arid terrain makes him feel “sad” and “hopeless,” putting him in the worst mental state. But upon seeing the fish camp, he feels relieved, and the positive effect of the setting changes his mental state from negative to positive. Overall, the setting is the primary factor determining the cyclist's physical and mental states, having nearly equal positive and negative impacts in the story.

The setting made the cyclist experience loneliness. Since the cyclist saw no people or water on the way, hope quickly faded. The cyclist described seeing a “ghost town.” Before reaching the fish camp, the cyclist was alone and becoming dehydrated. This led to a loss of hope, and at times, the cyclist thought they were going to die, as evidenced by the statement “I was going to die and the birds would pick me clean.” Clearly, the setting had a highly negative impact on the cyclist.

The cyclist embarked on a journey through a forest. The features of this forest setting presented a bumpy and long - drawn - out trip filled with numerous troubles. Despite the challenges, the cyclist persevered and managed to complete the journey, emerging with a story to share. In conclusion, the forest setting, with its difficulties, tested the cyclist but also became the backdrop for an eventful adventure.

In the essay “Rough Road Ahead: Do Not Exceed Posted Speed Limit,” the setting has an impact on the cyclist's physical and emotional state. At the start of the essay, the cyclist “rode into the morning with strong legs and a smile on [his] face.” The morning was not overly hot, so the cyclist was happy, strong, and confident that he could overcome any obstacle. As the day progressed, “the sun was beginning to beat down.” Although the cyclist was drinking a lot of water, he remained confident and strong. However, when he came across “a ramshackle shed [and] several rusty pumps,” the sight troubled him. Traveling in the hot deserts of California, the cyclist grew tired and thirsty, having to conserve water. What began as a confident ride into the desert turned into a survival ride. Once the cyclist found water, he felt relieved, more confident, and was able to continue to his destination. Just as in the essay, the weather and setting can affect us both physically and emotionally, as the cyclist became physically and emotionally exhausted as the hot, sunny day wore on.

At the start of the journey, the cyclist was confident and excited after receiving new directions from some “old wise men” that promised a shortcut. With a mediocre water supply, the cyclist set off with determination against the flat and hilly terrain. However, he soon realized that the directions were inaccurate. While on his way to Yosemite, the cyclist came across what he thought was a town, but it was more of a ghostly place. As he continued, hoping the shortcut would materialize, he found himself alone in the hot desert with a dwindling water supply and a fading spirit. He was remorseful for following the advice of the old men. Through his pain and despair, he decided never to listen to such people again. By rationing water and mentally focusing on each hill one at a time, the cyclist endured physical, emotional, and mental trials. In the end, he learned a valuable lesson: never consult old “codgers” on mapping issues, as their information is likely to be outdated.

The reason the setting affected the cyclist is that the hotter it got, the more water he drank. Additionally, the farther he traveled, the more tired he became. This tiredness made him hotter, which in turn caused him to drink more of his water.

The features of the setting significantly impacted the cyclist during his determined ride. Initially, he seemed relaxed, chatting about the cool pines and rushing rivers he'd encounter upon reaching Yosemite. After a grueling ride, he began to feel nervous and wondered if he'd even survive. He was running out of water and thought he saw a diamondback. When he reached the rolling hills, he noticed a posted speed - limit sign stating not to exceed 55 m.p.h., while he was only going at a water - depleting 12 m.p.h., constantly worrying about his survival. At the end of the rolling hills, he came across an old Welch's grape factory and lamented how cruel his life was. After that, he resolved to survive and reach his destination. He spotted some landmarks on the horizon and rode towards them, making his way across the desert. Finally, he arrived at "Only and Wilbers fish camp", where he knew he was safe and would survive.

In Joe Kurmaskie's story "Rough Road Ahead," a cyclist embarked on a bike ride in the sweltering California summer while staying there. When the road is long, downhill, and cool, the cyclist has no issues. However, when faced with straight uphill roads and extreme heat, the cyclist struggles to keep pedaling.
